Comment: Prevents Ng5 and also restricts future movement of my black bishop along that diagonal.

Hence, I prepare to fiancetto the bishop instead. I had to be careful not to over-extend my white bishop here.
This pin was somewhat problematic. Nd4 could put a lot of pressure on the pinned knight.
This pin was somewhat problematic. Nd4 could put a lot of pressure on the pinned knight.
This pin was somewhat problematic. Nd4 could put a lot of pressure on the pinned knight.

So I proceeded to pin his knight. I hadn't intended for this to happen as I really wanted that white bishop controlling the diagonal on his king-side from d3 eventually. However, given my position, I was now prepared to trade the bishop for the knight and get him a doubled-pawn structure on the queen-side.

Looked like he wanted to castle. Nd4 seemed dangerous, but not yet (and even after O-O-O). I was going to fiancetto, shore up my positions with my rook before withdrawing the bishop to a safer location (or exchange for the knight if forced to do so).

Looked like he wanted to castle. Nd4 seemed dangerous, but not yet (and even after O-O-O). I was going to fiancetto, shore up my positions with my rook before withdrawing the bishop to a safer location (or exchange for the knight if forced to do so).
Critical blunder. My queen was safe.
Critical blunder. My queen was safe.

He could still fight, since my position was cramped. My plan was to get the queen to safety while defending the c pawn, eventually freeing pieces for an attack through Nd5. At this point, the overall plan was to force as many piece exchanges as possible without jeopardizing the queen.
